Understanding Server Configurations

After the Server has been installed, an administrator must create an instance (known as a server configuration) on the computer running the Server. At least one server configuration must be created before users can use an application client.

A server configuration serves as a repository for application projects. It defines:

  • The set of options, including endpoints and encryption levels, used for server access.

  • Location of the database that stores project data, the database DSN, and other related information. See the StarTeam Installation Guide for information about specific databases.

  • Locations of the repository and repository-related files and folders.

Other server configuration settings control where, when, how, and by whom the data is accessed. Some initial settings for the server configuration are properties that are necessary to start the Server. For example, if the user name and password that allow the Server to access the database are not accurate, the Server cannot run. To meet your organization's requirements, these properties can be changed by an administrator before starting the server.

The Server can have any number of server configurations. But if more than one configuration runs at the same time on the same computer, each configuration must use a different endpoint.

Any number of projects can be associated with a particular server configuration. Typically, users add or delete server configurations from the list of available server configurations on their workstations to access the projects on which they will work.

 

See also Creating a Server Configuration.
